Comments_List: I developed computational skills that are very valuable in modern Macroeconomics. I learned how to use specific programs like Python and how to use specific techniques in order to solve models.
numerical methods to solve dynamic programming problem
Fortran and different ways to code dynamic programming problems
Fortran programming, numerical methods theory, idea of directions for further reading if these methods aren't sufficient in my research.
Writing code in Fortran, basic numerical methods, also VFI methods.
Slides would increase the structure of the class. Following the instructor was sometimes difficult due to him jumping between topics.
Strengths: It covers various computational methods, ranging from the basics, such as Newton-Raphson method, up to cubic splines.

Great survey of numerical methods, good, intuitive explanations in class, liked the broad coverage.  Would be nice to devote more time to applications as noted in the syllabus--maybe replace the last two weeks of numerical methods with applications, covering, for example, environmental applications in more depth. The last two weeks were a bit abstract and I think a lot of us didn't follow the details.
A bit slow in the beginning for grad students

Strengths: lots of methods
Improvement: I wish we had read some of the papers on the syllabus

Yes, I think it teaches the necessary tools that every student in Economics should be familiar with. Also the course content was well structured and did not emphasize any part of economics more than another.
I would recommend it because it is very important to know computational methods nowadays.
yes; learning numerical methods is just important
Yes, I would recommend to anyone who might use numerical methods in their research.  Hard to imagine using these methods or learning Fortran without taking this class.
